content: Unfortunately, the most frequently suggested 'solution' to your problem that I've seen here is to shut down the VPN. But I respect that's not your plan. When trying 465, did you also try both STARTTLS and SSL/TLS? Another possibility might be to contact the VPN provider to see if you can be whitelisted.

content:
Have you tried clearing the cache? they is a button in settings and in the troubleshooting information on the help menu. If that does not work try right clicking the folder, selecting properties and then the repair button.

The issue is Yahoo, their servers have a bug, and have had a bug for years.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thank you. I cleared the cache just now, and will see if anything changes in the sent folder in a while. I did the Repair again, and got the same error message that I mentioned in my post. I was considering deleting the Yahoo account and adding it again, but this might just invite more problems?
creator: VonZipper

content: Yes, some email providers have a recall option, but only when the email provider has a central server setup, such as that provided by Groupmail. BUT email clients typically do not work with a centralized server. When you send a message, the email client (not just Thunderbird) sends the message to the SMTP server and it is out of the sender's control from then on. So, once a message is sent, it cannot be retrieved. Note: When sending a message, there is a 'cancel' button, but that only applies during the brief se.cond that Thunderbird is initiating contact with the SMTP server.

content:
Hello there We have read the question We try to help you


Try starting the Thunderbird add-ons and software in safe mode for Thunderbird with add-ons disabled, software in networking, and you can also disable the add-ons or have them run automatically. If your program can send emails again, it could have been a bad add-on that was hindering your traffic Now try to boot it for your operating system in safe mode for Windows or boot another operating system you are using, just like the situation in the previous topic when troubleshooting for Thunderbird cannot be found on your PC. Try the same thing and see if you can find incorrectly installed software in this case or AV software, firewalls, download software or other scanning programs that get in the way of your other software and prevent email traffic from working properly. Most likely, safe mode or trouble shooting for Thunderbird will automatically solve your problem. If not, you can do this manually.

To enter troubleshoot mode, keep pressing the f button when starting your software. If you are already in the program itself, you can go to the help options and choose the trouble shoot mode and then press restart in the menu for this.

You can also look for the option to boot your Win 11 in safe mode.


Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird
